0:
A Clockwork Orange
by Anthony Burgess

A Clockwork Orange is a dystopian novel by Anthony Burgess, published in 1962. The novel follows the violent adventures of a teenager named Alex, who is a member of a vicious gang of criminals. The book is written in a unique style that merges elements of science fiction, horror, and comedy.
1:
A Confederacy of Dunces
by John Kennedy Toole

The book "A Confederacy of Dunces" by John Kennedy Toole is a hilarious satire set in New Orleans. The story follows the misadventures of the lazy, overweight and obnoxiously opinionated Ignatius J. Reilly. Despite its age, the book is still relevant today and its humor is timeless.
2:
A Farewell to Arms
by Ernest Hemingway

"A Farewell to Arms" is a novel by Ernest Hemingway about an American ambulance driver in Italy during World War I, and his love affair with an English nurse. The novel is set against the backdrop of the war and explores themes of love, loss, and betrayal.
3:
A Passage to India
by E. M. Forster

A Passage to India is a book by E.M. Forster set in British India in the early 1900s. The book is about the relationships between the British and the Indians, and the misunderstandings that can occur between them. The book is considered a classic of English literature.
4:
A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
by James Joyce

A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man is a semi-autobiographical novel by James Joyce, first published in 1916. The work chronicles the formative years in the life of Stephen Dedalus, a fictional alter ego of Joyce and an allusion to the Greek mythological character Daedalus. The novel, a kunstlerroman, follows Stephen from the first stirrings of his artistic conscience in childhood through his attempts as an adolescent to reconcile his family's Catholic and nationalist traditions with his own desire to forge his own path as an artist.
5:
A Prayer for Owen Meany
by John Irving

A Prayer for Owen Meany is a novel by John Irving. It is Irving's seventh novel, and was published in 1989. The novel is set in the 1950s and 1960s in the United States and Canada. It is a coming-of-age story about a boy with a deformity and his best friend.
6:
A Room With a View
by E. M. Forster

A Room With a View is a novel by E. M. Forster about a young woman named Lucy Honeychurch who goes to Italy on vacation and has a number of adventures. The book is a comedy of manners and a romance.
7:
A Season in Hell
by Arthur Rimbaud

A Season in Hell is a book of verse written by Arthur Rimbaud. The book is considered to be an early example of modernist poetry. The book is divided into two sections, with the first section being a prose poem and the second section being a collection of verse. The book chronicles the descent into hell of the narrator, who is undergoing a spiritual crisis.
8:
A Sentimental Education
by Gustave Flaubert

A Sentimental Education is a novel by Gustave Flaubert, published in 1869. The novel is set during the years leading up to the 1848 Revolution and describes the growth of the protagonist, Frederic Moreau, from youthful innocence to disillusionment.
9:
A Tree Grows in Brooklyn
by Betty Smith

"A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" is a 1943 novel by Betty Smith. The book tells the story of an impoverished but determined young girl, Francie Nolan, growing up in the Williamsburg slums of Brooklyn, New York, during the early 20th century. The novel is set primarily in the 1910s and 1920s.
10:
Absalom, Absalom!
by William Faulkner

The book "Absalom, Absalom!" is a novel by William Faulkner. It is set in the American South during the Civil War and Reconstruction era. The story is told from the perspective of multiple characters, including the young man Thomas Sutpen and his father, Henry. The novel explores themes of race, morality, and family.
11:
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
by Lewis Carroll

Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is a novel by Lewis Carroll that was first published in 1865. The novel is a fantasy story that follows Alice, a young girl, as she falls down a rabbit hole into a strange and fantastical world. The novel has been widely praised for its imaginative and whimsical storytelling.
12:
All Quiet on the Western Front
by Erich Maria Remarque

"All Quiet on the Western Front" is a novel by Erich Maria Remarque, published in 1928. The novel is set during World War I and is about the German experience of the war. The novel is told from the perspective of a German soldier, Paul BÃ¤umer, and follows his experiences from training to the front line and ultimately to his death.
13:
All the King's Men
by Robert Penn Warren

"All the King's Men" is a novel by Robert Penn Warren about the rise and fall of a politician in the American South. The novel is told through the eyes of Jack Burden, a reporter who becomes the right-hand man to Willie Stark, a corrupt politician. The novel won the Pulitzer Prize in 1947.
14:
Animal Farm
by George Orwell

Animal Farm is a novel by George Orwell. The novel is about the rise of the Soviet Union and the rebellion against it. The novel is a satire of the Soviet Union and its leaders. The novel is also an allegory for the problems with socialism.
15:
Anna Karenina
by Leo Tolstoy

Anna Karenina is a novel by the Russian writer Leo Tolstoy, first published in serial installments in the periodical The Russian Messenger from 1873 to 1877. It is regarded as a co-founder of the tradition of the psychological novel in world literature. The story centers on the life of Anna Karenina, a married aristocratic woman, and her affair with the affluent Count Vronsky. The novel examines the lives of many characters, including friends and family members of the Karenina and Vronsky families, and illustrates the disastrous consequences of breaking the norms of Russian society.
16:
Antigone
by Sophocles

Sophocles's Antigone is a tragic play about a young woman who goes against her uncle's orders and gives her brother a proper burial, despite the fact that he is a traitor. As a result, she is put to death. The play is a timeless story about the conflict between an individual's conscience and the state.
17:
As I Lay Dying
by William Faulkner

The book "As I Lay Dying" is a novel by William Faulkner, which was first published in 1930. It is told in the first person by 15 different characters, and is set in Mississippi in the early 20th century. The book is about the death of a woman, Addie Bundren, and her family's journey to bury her.
18:
Atonement
by Ian McEwan

Atonement is a novel by Ian McEwan published in 2001. It is a historical fiction novel set in the 1930s and 1940s England. The novel is about a young girl, Briony Tallis, who falsely accuses her older sister's lover of a crime he did not commit. The novel follows the consequences of this accusation throughout the lives of Briony, her sister, and the man she accused.
19:
Austerlitz
by W. G. Sebald

"Austerlitz" is a novel by W. G. Sebald, published in 2001. The book is about the life of a man named Jacques Austerlitz, who was born in Czechoslovakia but raised in England. Austerlitz discovers his true identity and history when he visits the Czech Republic. The novel is a mix of genres, including history, autobiography, and travel writing.
20:
Beloved
by Toni Morrison

"Beloved" is a novel by Toni Morrison. It was published in 1987 and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1988. The novel is set in the aftermath of the American Civil War and is inspired by the true story of an enslaved woman who killed her child rather than have her returned to slavery.
21:
Bleak House
by Charles Dickens

"Bleak House" by Charles Dickens is a novel that follows the lives of several characters in London during the Victorian era. The novel is a satire of the legal system at the time, and Dickens uses his characters to critiques the class structure of British society. The plot follows the characters as they navigate the complexities of the law and their relationships with each other.
22:
Blood Meridian
by Cormac McCarthy

"Blood Meridian" is a novel by Cormac McCarthy set in the 1850s. It tells the story of the Kid, a 14-year-old boy, who becomes a murderer and scalper and joins a group of mercenaries known as the Glanton gang. The novel is a Western, but it is also a brutal and violent story.
23:
Bonfire of the Vanities
by Tom Wolfe

The Bonfire of the Vanities is a novel by Tom Wolfe published in 1987. The novel is set in New York City during the 1980s. The story follows Sherman McCoy, a wealthy white bond trader, who becomes embroiled in a scandal after he accidentally hits and kills a black teenager with his car. The novel explores themes of race, class, and power in New York City.
24:
Brave New World
by Aldous Huxley

"Brave New World" is a dystopian novel by Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932. Largely set in a futuristic World State, whose citizens are technologically engineered into an intelligence-based social hierarchy, the novel anticipates huge scientific advancements in reproductive technology, sleep-learning, psychology and classical conditioning that could be used to change society.
25:
Buddenbrooks
by Thomas Mann

Buddenbrooks is a novel by German author Thomas Mann, published in 1901. It is the story of the decline of a wealthy Hanseatic merchant family of LÃ¼beck during the early 19th century. The novel is based on Mann's own family history. It was Mann's first novel and garnered him much critical acclaim.
26:
Candide
by Voltaire

"Candide" is a French satire written by Voltaire in the 18th century. The story follows the adventures of the young Candide, who is Optimistic about everything despite all the evidence to the contrary. The book is a satire of the Optimism philosophy, and its journey is a Candide's search for the meaning of life.
27:
Catch-22
by Joseph Heller

Catch-22 is a novel by Joseph Heller that was first published in 1961. The book is set during World War II and follows the story of Captain John Yossarian, a U.S. Army Air Forces B-25 bomber pilot. Yossarian is stationed on the island of Pianosa and is trying to figure out a way to stay alive. The novel is a satire of war and bureaucracy and is considered one of the most important works of twentieth-century literature.
28:
Charlotte's Web
by E. B. White

Charlotte's Web is a children's novel by E. B. White. The book tells the story of a young pig named Wilbur who befriends a spider named Charlotte. Together, they work to save Wilbur from being slaughtered. The book was published in 1952 and has won several awards, including a Newbery Honor.
29:
Collected Fiction
by Jorge Luis Borges

"Collected Fiction" by Jorge Luis Borges is a collection of short stories by the Argentine author. The stories are written in a range of different genres, including fantasy, science fiction, and detective fiction. Many of the stories feature Borges' trademark labyrinthine plotting, and several are metafictional in nature.
30:
Collected Poems of W. B. Yeats
by W. B. Yeats

The Collected Poems of W. B. Yeats is a collection of poems by W. B. Yeats. The poems are organized into sections by topic, such as "Love Poems", "Nature Poems", and "Political Poems". The collection also includes some of Yeats' most famous poems, such as "The Lake Isle of Innisfree" and "The Second Coming".
31:
Confessions of Zeno
by Italo Svevo

Confessions of Zeno is a novel by Italo Svevo, first published in 1923. It is the story of a man's life told through a series of confessions to his analyst, Dr. S. The novel is set in Trieste and is a modernist work, influenced by James Joyce and Sigmund Freud.
32:
Cousin Bette
by HonorÃ© de Balzac

Cousin Bette is a novel by HonorÃ© de Balzac, first published in 1846. The novel follows the decline of the middle-class Hulot family and the machinations of the title character, who is determined to see her cousin's descendants ruined.
33:
Crime and Punishment
by Fyodor Dostoyevsky

"Crime and Punishment" by Fyodor Dostoyevsky is a novel about a young man who kills an old woman and her sister for money. The novel explores the psychological and moral implications of the crime, as well as the social and political context in which it takes place.
34:
Dangerous Liaison
by Pierre Choderlos de Laclos

"Dangerous Liaison" is a novel by Pierre Choderlos de Laclos, first published in 1782. The novel is set in France during the 18th century and is a story of seduction and betrayal. The novel has been adapted into a number of stage and screen productions.
35:
David Copperfield
by Charles Dickens

"David Copperfield" is a novel by Charles Dickens, published in 1850. It is the story of the titular character, David Copperfield, from his birth to adulthood. The novel is told in the first person, as David tells his own story. It is a coming-of-age story, as well as a Bildungsroman, and follows David as he grows up, makes friends and enemies, falls in and out of love, and experiences all the joys and sorrows of life.
36:
Dead Souls
by Nikolai Gogol

Dead Souls by Nikolai Gogol is a novel about a man named Chichikov who goes around buying the souls of dead serfs from landowners in order to get a better head count for the census. It is considered one of the first works of Russian literature and is a classic example of the absurdist genre.
37:
Decameron
by Giovanni Boccaccio

The Decameron by Giovanni Boccaccio is a collection of novellas written in the 14th century. The stories are set during the time of the Black Death, and focus on a group of seven young women and three young men who flee Florence in order to escape the plague. The book is considered to be one of the earliest and most important works of fiction in Western literature.
38:
Doctor Faustus
by Thomas Mann

"Doctor Faustus" is a novel by Thomas Mann, first published in 1947. The novel is set in Germany during the First World War and the interwar period, and describes the decline of the artist Adrian LeverkÃ¼hn as he contracts syphilis. It is a work of modernist fiction, and is considered one of the most important works of the 20th century.
39:
Doctor Zhivago
by Boris Pasternak

Doctor Zhivago is a novel by Boris Pasternak, first published in 1957. The novel is set against the backdrop of the Russian Revolution and the Russian Civil War. The story follows the life of Yuri Zhivago, a doctor and poet, as he struggles to survive in the midst of the turmoil.
40:
Don Quixote
by Miguel de Cervantes

"Don Quixote" is a novel by Miguel de Cervantes. It is a satire of chivalric romances and follows the adventures of an aging man who, after reading too many stories of knights and their quests, decides to become one himself. Along with his trusted squire, Sancho Panza, he sets out on a series of comical and often tragic adventures.
41:
Dracula
by Bram Stoker

Dracula is a novel by Bram Stoker, first published in 1897. It tells the story of Count Dracula's attempt to move from Transylvania to England so that he may find new blood and spread the undead curse, and of the battle between Dracula and a small group of people led by Professor Abraham Van Helsing.
42:
Emma
by Jane Austen

"Emma" is a novel by Jane Austen that was first published in 1815. The novel is set in the fictional town of Highbury in England and follows the life and relationships of the protagonist, Emma Woodhouse. "Emma" is a novel of manners that satirizes the social customs of the time.
43:
Epic of Gilgamesh
by Unknown

The Epic of Gilgamesh is a book that tells the story of Gilgamesh, a man who is two-thirds god and one-third human. Gilgamesh is the king of the city of Uruk and is considered to be the strongest and most intelligent man in the world. The book tells the story of his journey to find immortality and his eventual death. The book is considered to be one of the first works of literature and is still studied by scholars today.
44:
Eugenie Grandet
by HonorÃ© de Balzac

"Eugenie Grandet" is a novel by HonorÃ© de Balzac. It is set in the fictional town of Saumur in the Loire Valley during the early 19th century. The story follows the life of Eugenie Grandet, a young woman who is forced to live a life of poverty and hardship after her father's death. Despite her difficult circumstances, Eugenie remains a kind and compassionate person, and the novel explores the themes of love, loss, and forgiveness.
45:
Fahrenheit 451
by Ray Bradbury

Fahrenheit 451 is a dystopian novel by Ray Bradbury, first published in 1953. It presents a future American society where books are outlawed and "firemen" burn any that are found. The story is set in a city where literature is on the brink of extinction.
46:
Fairy Tales and Stories
by Hans Christian Anderson

"Fairy Tales and Stories" by Hans Christian Anderson is a book of fairy tales and stories written by the Danish author. The book contains some of Anderson's most famous stories, such as "The Ugly Duckling" and "The Emperor's New Clothes". The tales are often humorous and sometimes tragic, but always provide a moral lesson.
47:
Father Goriot
by HonorÃ© de Balzac

Father Goriot is a novel by HonorÃ© de Balzac, published in 1835. The novel is set in Paris in the early 19th century and follows the lives of a group of characters from various social backgrounds. The novel is considered a masterpiece of realism and is often cited as one of the greatest novels of all time.
48:
Fathers and Sons
by Ivan Turgenev

Fathers and Sons is a novel by Ivan Turgenev that was first published in 1862. The novel is set in Russia in the 1860s and focuses on the clash between two generations and the resulting tensions in Russian society. The novel is considered a masterpiece of Russian realist literature.
49:
Faust
by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

Faust is a tragic play in two parts by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. It is Goethe's most famous work and considered by many to be one of the greatest works of German literature. The play tells the story of a young scholar, Faust, who makes a pact with the devil, Mephistopheles, in order to gain knowledge and power. The pact leads to tragedy when Faust is led astray by his lust for a young woman, Gretchen.
50:
Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream
by Hunter S. Thompson

The book is a semi-autobiographical account of the author's experiences in Las Vegas. It is a satire of the American Dream, and is widely considered to be one of the most influential works of the counterculture. The plot revolves around the characters' search for the American Dream, and their eventual descent into madness.
51:
For Whom the Bell Tolls
by Ernest Hemingway

"For Whom the Bell Tolls" by Ernest Hemingway, published in 1940, is a novel about the Spanish Civil War. The story follows Robert Jordan, an American who has joined the Republican forces fighting against the Nationalists, as he helps blow up a bridge. The novel is considered a classic of Hemingway's work.
52:
Frankenstein
by Mary Shelley

Frankenstein is a novel by Mary Shelley published in 1818. It tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a hideous, sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment. Shelley started writing the novel when she was eighteen, and the first edition was published anonymously in London in 1818. Shelley's name first appeared on the second edition, published in 1831.
53:
Gargantua and Pantagruel
by Francois Rabelais

"Gargantua and Pantagruel" is a novel by Francois Rabelais, first published in 1534. It is a satire of the medieval chivalric romance and is considered one of the greatest works of French Renaissance literature. The novel tells the story of two giants, Gargantua and his son Pantagruel, and their adventures.
54:
Gone With the Wind
by Margaret Mitchell

Gone With the Wind is a novel by Margaret Mitchell, first published in 1936. The novel tells the story of Scarlett O'Hara, the strong-willed daughter of a Georgia plantation owner, from the American Civil War through the Reconstruction era. The novel is one of the most popular books of all time, and was adapted into a 1939 film of the same name.
55:
Great Expectations
by Charles Dickens

"Great Expectations" by Charles Dickens is a novel that follows the life of Pip, an orphan who tries to make something of himself. The novel is set in Victorian England and Pip must deal with classism, love, and betrayal.
56:
Gulliver's Travels
by Jonathan Swift

"Gulliver's Travels" by Jonathan Swift is a satire of the political and social issues of the day. The book is divided into four parts, each of which tells the story of Gulliver's travels to a different country. In the first part, Gulliver is shipwrecked on an island inhabited by tiny people, the Lilliputians. The second part tells of Gulliver's journey to the land of the giants, Brobdingnag. The third part takes place in the land of the Houyhnhnms, where Gulliver learns that the horse is the superior species and that humans are little better than animals. In the final part, Gulliver returns to England, where he is disgusted by the hypocrisy and corruption he finds there.
57:
Hamlet
by William Shakespeare

"Hamlet" by William Shakespeare is a tragedy about the titular character, Hamlet, who seeks revenge on his uncle for murdering his father and taking the throne. The play is full of intrigue, betrayal, and murder, and is widely considered to be one of Shakespeare's best works.
58:
Heart of Darkness
by Joseph Conrad

"Heart of Darkness" is a novel by Joseph Conrad, published in 1899. The novelHeart of Darkness is set primarily in Congo and chronicles Marlow's journey up the Congo River to meet Kurtz, who has been accused of brutality and murder.
59:
Howards End
by E. M. Forster

"Howards End" by E. M. Forster is a novel about class relations in early 20th century England. The story centers on the relationship between Margaret Schlegel, a middle-class woman, and Henry Wilcox, a wealthy businessman. Margaret and Henry come from different social backgrounds, and their relationship is complicated by the interference of Henry's son, Charles.
60:
In Search of Lost Time
by Marcel Proust

In Search of Lost Time is a novel by Marcel Proust. The novel is about the narrator's experience of time and memory. The novel is divided into seven parts, each part dealing with a different aspect of the narrator's life. The novel has been described as a work of philosophy, a work of fiction, and a work of autobiography.
61:
Independent People
by Halldor Laxness

"Independent People" is a novel by Halldor Laxness that was published in 1935. The novel tells the story of Bjartur of Summerhouses, a sheep farmer in Iceland, and his fight to maintain his independence. The book is considered to be one of the great works of Icelandic literature.
62:
Invisible Man
by Ralph Ellison

Invisible Man is a novel by Ralph Ellison about an unnamed African American man who goes through life without being truly seen or understood. The novel explores themes of identity, race, and politics in America. The novel is considered a classic of American literature and won the National Book Award in 1953.
63:
Jane Eyre
by Charlotte Bronte

"Jane Eyre" is a novel by Charlotte Bronte. It was published in 1847 and is considered one of the first feminist novels. The novel is about a young woman, Jane Eyre, who is hired as a governess by Mr. Rochester, a wealthy man. After Mr. Rochester proposes to her, she discovers that he is already married to a woman who is insane and locked in the attic. Jane then leaves Mr. Rochester and goes to live with her cousin, St. John.
64:
Journey to the End of The Night
by Louis-Ferdinand CÃ©line

"Journey to the End of the Night" is a novel by Louis-Ferdinand CÃ©line. The novel follows the life of Ferdinand Bardamu, a French doctor and World War I veteran, as he travels from France to the United States and then to Africa. The novel is highly critical of the human condition, and its style is characterized by its use of violence and obscenity.
65:
Jude the Obscure
by Thomas Hardy

"Jude the Obscure" is a novel by Thomas Hardy, first published in 1895. The book tells the story of Jude Fawley, a working-class man who tries to make his way in the world by getting an education. The novel is a tragedy, and Jude's story ends in tragedy.
66:
King Lear
by William Shakespeare

King Lear is a tragedy by William Shakespeare. The plot revolves around the titular character, who descends into madness after foolishly handing over his kingdom to two of his three daughters. The play is known for its powerful portrayal of family relationships and human suffering.
67:
Leaves of Grass
by Walt Whitman

"Leaves of Grass" is a collection of poems by Walt Whitman. The poems are about grass, nature, and love. They are written in a simple, natural style. The book is a good choice for readers who enjoy poems about nature and love.
68:
Les MisÃ©rables
by Victor Hugo

Les MisÃ©rables is a novel by French author Victor Hugo, first published in 1862. It is considered one of the greatest novels of the 19th century and is commonly referred to as one of the Western world's most influential books. The novel tells the story of Jean Valjean, a French peasant, and his journey from imprisonment and despair to forgiveness and redemption.
69:
Little Women
by Louisa May Alcott

"Little Women" is a novel by Louisa May Alcott, published in 1868. The novel follows the lives of four sisters - Meg, Jo, Beth and Amy March - as they grow up in New England during the American Civil War. The novel is set against the backdrop of the war and is a classic example of the coming-of-age story.
70:
Lolita
by Vladimir Nabokov

"Lolita" is a novel by Vladimir Nabokov, first published in 1955. The book is written in English and is Nabokov's most famous work. It is the story of a middle-aged man's obsession with a 12-year-old girl. Lolita has been translated into many languages and has been adapted into film and stage productions.
71:
Lord Jim
by Joseph Conrad

"Lord Jim" by Joseph Conrad is a novel about a young man who, after being disgraced, joins a merchant ship and becomes its captain. The novel deals with themes of betrayal, morality, and redemption.
72:
Lord of the Flies
by William Golding

"Lord of the Flies" by William Golding is a novel about a group of boys who are stranded on an island and must fend for themselves. The novel is a allegory for the human condition and human nature. The boys are forced to confront the dark side of human nature in order to survive.
73:
Lost Illusions
by HonorÃ© de Balzac

"Lost Illusions" by HonorÃ© de Balzac, is a novel about a young man named Lucien de RubemprÃ© who leaves his provincial home for Paris in search of love and success as a poet. 74:
Love in the Time of Cholera
by Gabriel Garcia Marquez

"Love in the Time of Cholera" by Gabriel Garcia Marquez is a novel about a love triangle set in a small town in Colombia. It is a story of unrequited love and its effects on the lives of the three main characters.
75:
Macbeth
by William Shakespeare

Macbeth is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare. The play Macbeth is about the rise and fall of the title character, Macbeth. Macbeth is a brave warrior who is enticed by ambition and a prophecy to kill his king and take his place. Macbeth's actions have dire consequences for himself and for Scotland. The play is a study of how power corrupts and how ambition can lead to ruin.
76:
Madame Bovary
by Gustave Flaubert

"Madame Bovary" is a novel by Gustave Flaubert, published in 1856. The novel is set in provincial France in the early 19th century and follows the lives of Charles Bovary, a doctor, and his wife Emma. Emma is bored with her life and has an affair, which leads to tragedy.
77:
Medea
by Euripides

Written by Euripides, Medea is a Greek tragedy that tells the story of a woman who exacts revenge upon the man who betrayed her. The play is set in Corinth, where Medea has taken refuge after being exiled from her home in Colchis. She is married to Jason, who has abandoned her for another woman. Enraged, Medea takes revenge upon Jason by murdering his new bride and their two children. The play is a tragedy, and it ends with Medea being banished from Corinth.
78:
Metamorphoses
by Ovid

The book "Metamorphoses" by Ovid is a collection of myths that tell the stories of transformation of various beings into different forms. The book includes tales of gods and mortals, and their transformations into animals, plants, and objects. The book is considered a classic work of mythology and has been influential in many subsequent works of literature.
79:
Middlemarch
by George Eliot

Middlemarch is a novel by George Eliot, first published in 1871. It is set in the fictional town of Middlemarch in England, and tells the story of several residents of the town and their lives and interactions. The novel is considered a classic of English literature and has been praised for its realism, intelligence, and psychological insight.
80:
Midnight's Children
by Salman Rushdie

Midnight's Children is a novel by Salman Rushdie that was first published in 1981. It is set in India and tells the story of a group of children born at the stroke of midnight on the day of India's independence. The novel is a magical realism story about the children's lives and how they are affected by the political events of their country.
81:
Moby Dick
by Herman Melville

"Moby Dick" is an 1851 novel by Herman Melville, and is considered one of the Great American Novels. The novel tells the story of Ishmael, a sailor, who signs up for a whaling voyage as a means of escape from his mundane life. On this voyage, he becomes obsessed with the captain, Ahab's, quest to kill a giant white sperm whale, Moby Dick. The novel is full of themes of good vs. evil, nature vs. civilization, and man's place in the universe.
82:
Mrs. Dalloway
by Virginia Woolf

"Mrs. Dalloway" is a novel written by Virginia Woolf and published in 1925. The novel follows its protagonist, Clarissa Dalloway, through a day in her life in London. Along the way, Clarissa reflects on her past and the choices she has made in her life. "Mrs. Dalloway" is considered a modernist novel for its innovative use of stream-of-consciousness narration.
83:
My Antonia
by Willa Cather

"My Antonia" by Willa Cather is a novel about a young girl, Antonia, who moves to the American frontier. The novel follows her life as she grows up, gets married, and has children. The novel is set in the late 19th century and is a portrait of frontier life.
84:
Native Son
by Richard Wright

Native Son is a novel by Richard Wright. It is set in the 1930s in Chicago and tells the story of Bigger Thomas, a black man who is accused of murdering a white woman. The novel explores the themes of racism, violence, and poverty.
85:
Nineteen Eighty Four
by George Orwell

"Nineteen Eighty Four" is a novel by George Orwell. It is a political satire set in a dystopian society where the government controls everything. The story follows the life of Winston Smith, a government worker who starts to rebel against the system.
86:
Nineteen Nineteen
by John Dos Passos

"Nineteen Nineteen" by John Dos Passos is a novel that tells the story of two young men, Robert Wheeler and John Andrews, who are caught up in the First World War. The novel follows their lives as they experience the horrors of war and the aftermath of the conflict.
87:
Nostromo
by Joseph Conrad

Nostromo by Joseph Conrad is a novel set in the fictional South American country of Costaguana. The novel's protagonist, Nostromo, is a native of the country who works as a silver mine manager and is known for his loyalty and honesty. When political unrest threatens the stability of the country, Nostromo is tasked with transporting a shipment of silver out of the country, but he is betrayed and the silver is lost. Nostromo must then find a way to restore his reputation and save the country from ruin.
88:
Oedipus at Colonus
by Sophocles

"Oedipus at Colonus" is a tragedy by Sophocles written in 401 BC. It is one of the three Theban plays and tells the story of Oedipus, a tragic hero, who leaves Thebes after he is exiled. He wanders the countryside until he finds the grove of the Eumenides, where he is protected by the Furies. He dies there and his body is transformed into a holy site.
89:
Oedipus the King
by Sophocles

The book "Oedipus the King" by Sophocles is a tragedy. The plot of the book is that Oedipus, the king of Thebes, finds out that he killed his father and married his mother. Oedipus then blinds himself and goes into exile.
90:
Of Mice and Men
by John Steinbeck

The book is about two men, George and Lennie, who are ranch workers in California during the Great Depression. The novel has been classified as a tragedy, and it tells the story of the two men's struggles to make their dream of owning their own farm come true.
91:
On the Road
by Jack Kerouac

On the Road is a novel by Jack Kerouac, published in 1957. It is considered a defining work of the postwar Beat and Counterculture generations, with its protagonists living life against conventional social expectations, and exploring America and their own identities through jazz, poetry, and drug use.
92:
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
by Ken Kesey

"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is a novel by Ken Kesey set in a psychiatric hospital. The novel is a satire of the medical establishment and a critique of psychiatry. It is also an exploration of individual freedom and rebellion. The story follows the main character, Randle Patrick McMurphy, as he is admitted to the hospital and attempts to overthrow the oppressive authority of the nurses.
93:
One Hundred Years of Solitude
by Gabriel Garcia Marquez

One Hundred Years of Solitude (1967) is a novel by Gabriel Garcia Marquez that tells the story of the Buendia family, who live in the fictional town of Macondo. The novel is set over a hundred years, from the founding of Macondo to its destruction. One Hundred Years of Solitude is a classic work of magic realism, and is widely considered to be one of the greatest novels of the 20th century.
94:
One Thousand and One Nights
by India/Iran/Iraq/Egypt

"One Thousand and One Nights" is a book of Persian origin that was later translated into Arabic. It is a collection of folk tales and fairy tales that have been passed down orally for centuries. The most famous story from the book is "Aladdin and the Magic Lamp".
95:
Oresteia
by Aeschylus

"Oresteia" by Aeschylus is a classic Greek tragedy that tells the story of Orestes, who avenges his father's murder by killing his mother. The play explores the themes of justice and retribution, and the cycle of violence that can result from unresolved conflict.
96:
Orlando: A Biography
by Virginia Woolf

Orlando: A Biography is a novel by Virginia Woolf, first published in 1928. It is considered a feminist classic and is distinct from Woolf's other novels in that it is a fantasy, and features a protagonist who changes gender over the course of the story. The novel follows Orlando through several centuries, from the Elizabethan era to the early 20th century, and is based on the life of Woolf's friend and lover Vita Sackville-West.
97:
Pale Fire
by Vladimir Nabokov

"Pale Fire" is a novel by Vladimir Nabokov, first published in 1962. It is Nabokov's longest and most accomplished novel, and is considered one of the greatest works of 20th-century literature. The novel is presented as a 999-line poem titled "Pale Fire", written by the fictional John Shade, with commentary by Shade's friend and editor, Charles Kinbote. The poem is followed by Kinbote's lengthy and eccentric commentary, which gradually reveals that Shade and Kinbote are both unstable narrators.
98:
Paradise Lost
by John Milton

"Paradise Lost" is John Milton's epic poem about the fall of man. The poem follows Adam and Eve as they are tempted by Satan and fall from grace. The poem is written in blank verse and is considered one of the greatest works of literature.
99:
Pedro Paramo
by Juan Rulfo

Pedro Paramo by Juan Rulfo is a novel set in Mexico after the Mexican Revolution. The novel tells the story of Pedro Paramo, a man who returns to his hometown of Comala after his mother's death. Pedro Paramo is a dark and haunting novel that explores the themes of death, violence, and madness.
100:
Poems of Emily Dickinson
by Emily Dickinson

"Poems of Emily Dickinson" is a book of poetry by Emily Dickinson. The book contains over 1000 poems, many of which explore death, love, and nature. The poems are often short and written in simple language, making them accessible to a wide range of readers.
101:
Pride and Prejudice
by Jane Austen

Pride and Prejudice is a novel by Jane Austen, first published in 1813. The story follows the main character, Elizabeth Bennet, as she deals with issues of manners, upbringing, morality, education, and marriage in the society of the landed gentry of the British Regency.
102:
Rabbit Is Rich
by John Updike

The novel Rabbit Is Rich is the third installment in John Updike's Rabbit series, following Rabbit, Run and Rabbit Redux. The novel follows the life of Harry Angstrom, now in his early fifties, as he tries to deal with the constraints of middle age. It is a comic novel, and deals with themes of love, family, success, and mortality.
103:
Rabbit Redux
by John Updike

Rabbit Redux is a 1971 novel by John Updike. The novel is the second in a trilogy about the life of the character Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom. Set in the fictional town of Brewer, Pennsylvania, the novel deals with Angstrom's midlife crisis and contains elements of social satire. The novel was nominated for the National Book Award and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.
104:
Rabbit, Run
by John Updike

 Rabbit, Run is a novel by John Updike. The novel is set in the early 1960s in the fictional town of Brewer, Pennsylvania, and tells the story of a former high school basketball player named Harry Angstrom who is struggling to find meaning in his life. The novel is a tragedy, and it explores the themes of alienation, addiction, and redemption.
105:
Rebecca
by Daphne du Maurier

"Rebecca" is a novel by Daphne du Maurier. It is a gothic novel about a young woman, who is the second wife of a wealthy man, who is haunted by the memory of his first wife, Rebecca.
106:
Robinson Crusoe
by Daniel Defoe

"Robinson Crusoe" is an adventure novel by Daniel Defoe, first published in 1719. It tells the story of a shipwrecked sailor who spends 28 years on a remote island, encountering pirates, cannibals, and native inhabitants before being rescued. The novel is based on the true story of Alexander Selkirk, a Scottish sailor who was marooned on an island in the South Pacific for four years.
107:
Slaughterhouse-Five
by Kurt Vonnegut

"Slaughterhouse-Five" is a novel by Kurt Vonnegut about World War II. The novel is set in the fictional town of Ilium, New York, and chronicles the lives of Billy Pilgrim, a soldier who becomes "unstuck in time" and experiences moments from his life out of sequence. The novel is a commentary on the horrors of war and the futility of war.
108:
Sons and Lovers
by D. H. Lawrence

Sons and Lovers by D. H. Lawrence is a novel about the relationship between a mother and her sons. The novel explores the themes of love, betrayal, and family. The novel is set in England in the early 20th century.
109:
Stories of Ernest Hemingway
by Ernest Hemingway

"Stories of Ernest Hemingway" is a book of short stories written by Ernest Hemingway. The stories are sometimes funny, sometimes sad, but always interesting. They are about the human experience, and Hemingway's writing is beautiful and evocative. If you are a fan of Hemingway, or of short stories in general, this book is definitely worth reading.
110:
Tender Is the Night
by F. Scott Fitzgerald

"Tender Is the Night" is a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald. It is set in the 1920s and tells the story of a young couple, Dick and Nicole Diver, and their friends and associates. The novel is noted for its psychological insight and its portrait of the Jazz Age.
111:
Tess of the d'Urbervilles
by Thomas Hardy

Tess of the d'Urbervilles is a novel by Thomas Hardy, first published in 1891. The novel is set in the late Victorian era, and tells the story of Tess, a young woman from a working-class family, who falls in love with a wealthy landowner, Alec d'Urberville. When Tess is seduced and impregnated by Alec, she is forced to leave her home and seek work in the city. The novel follows Tess as she tries to make a new life for herself and her child, and ultimately ends in tragedy.
112:
The 42nd Parallel
by John Dos Passos

The 42nd Parallel is the first novel in John Dos Passos' USA Trilogy. The novel is set in the early 20th century and follows the lives of several Americans as they journey westward. As they travel, they are confronted with the harsh realities of life and the growing industrialization of the country. The novel is a portrait of America at the turn of the century, and its characters represent the different facets of the American experience.
113:
The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
by Mark Twain

The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is a novel by Mark Twain, published in 1884. The book's narrator is Huck Finn, a white boy who runs away from home and floats down the Mississippi River on a raft with a runaway slave, Jim. The story is set in the antebellum South and is a satire on slavery and racism.
114:
The Aeneid
by Virgil

The Aeneid is a Latin epic poem, written by Virgil between 29 and 19 BC, that tells the story of Aeneas, a Trojan who travelled to Italy, where he became the ancestor of the Romans. It is composed of 12 books, with over 10,000 lines of verse.
115:
The Age of Innocence
by Edith Wharton

The Age of Innocence is a 1920 novel by Edith Wharton. The novel won the 1921 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, making Wharton the first woman to win the prize. It is set in upper-class New York City in the 1870s. The story is about Newland Archer, a young lawyer, who is engaged to marry the beautiful socialite May Welland. However, Newland falls in love with May's cousin, the Countess Ellen Olenska, who is a scandalous woman who has left her abusive husband. Newland must choose between his duty to May and his love for Ellen.
116:
The Ambassadors
by Henry James

The book is a novel written by Henry James. It is a story about two American ambassadors who are sent to France on a mission to retrieve a wayward son. The novel is a study of human nature and explores the theme of self-discovery.
117:
The Big Money
by John Dos Passos

"The Big Money" by John Dos Passos is a novel about the rise of America as a world power through the eyes of three friends. The book is set in the early twentieth century and chronicles the lives of the three friends as they experience the highs and lows of success and failure. The book is a classic example of American literature and is considered to be one of the great works of the twentieth century.
118:
The Big Sleep
by Raymond Chandler

"The Big Sleep" by Raymond Chandler is a hard-boiled detective novel set in Los Angeles in the 1930s. The story follows private investigator Philip Marlowe as he tries to solve the murders of a wealthy family. The novel is known for its complex plot and its use of literary devices such as symbolism and irony.
119:
The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao
by Junot Diaz

The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao is a novel by Junot Diaz. The story follows the life of Oscar de Leon, a Dominican-American who is obsessed with science fiction and fantasy novels, and his family. The novel is set in the Dominican Republic and New Jersey, and explores the themes of family, identity, and the immigrant experience.
120:
The Brothers Karamazov
by Fyodor Dostoyevsky

The Brothers Karamazov is a novel by Fyodor Dostoyevsky, first published in 1879. It is the last of his major novels, and is considered one of his finest works. The Brothers Karamazov is a philosophical novel that explores the nature of good and evil, and their relationship to God. The story follows the lives of three brothers, Dmitri, Ivan, and Alexei, and their father, Fyodor Karamazov. The brothers are all very different, but are united in their love for their father, and in their quest to find the meaning of life.
121:
The Call of the Wild
by Jack London

The Call of the Wild is a novel by Jack London published in 1903. The novel's main character is a dog named Buck, who is brought from his life as a pet to the Klondike region of the Canadian Yukon during the 1890s Gold Rush. Buck must adapt to the harsh conditions and learn how to survive in the wild. The novel is considered a classic of American literature.
122:
The Canterbury Tales
by Geoffrey Chaucer

The Canterbury Tales is a book of 24 stories written by Geoffrey Chaucer in the late 1300s. The stories are about a group of pilgrims who are travelling to the shrine of Thomas Becket in Canterbury. The pilgrims tell each other stories to pass the time on their journey. The stories are a mix of comedy and tragedy, and they deal with topics like love, religion, and death.
123:
The Castle
by Franz Kafka

The book "The Castle" by Franz Kafka is a novel about a man who tries to get a job at a castle but is constantly thwarted by bureaucracy. It is a story about the human condition and the struggles we all face in trying to navigate the systems we live in.
124:
The Catcher in the Rye
by J. D. Salinger

The book "The Catcher in the Rye" is a novel by J.D. Salinger. The book follows Holden Caulfield, a teenager from New York City, who is expelled from his prep school and then takes a journey around America. The book is set in the 1950s and is a coming-of-age story.
125:
The Charterhouse of Parma
by Stendhal

"The Charterhouse of Parma" is a novel by Stendhal, published in 1839. It is a historical novel set in the Napoleonic era. The novel tells the story of Fabrizio, a young Italian man, who becomes caught up in the intrigue and drama of court life in Parma.
126:
The Color Purple
by Alice Walker

The Color Purple is a novel by Alice Walker that was published in 1982. It tells the story of an African-American woman named Celie, who is living in the American South in the early twentieth century. The novel covers themes of racism, sexism, and violence against women.
127:
The Complete Sherlock Holmes
by Arthur Conan Doyle

The book "The Complete Sherlock Holmes" is a collection of all the Sherlock Holmes stories written by Arthur Conan Doyle. The stories are mystery/detective stories that follow Sherlock Holmes and his partner Dr. Watson as they solve various crimes. The stories are set in Victorian England and are some of the first ever mystery stories written.
128:
The Complete Stories of Flannery O'Connor
by Flannery O'Connor

The Complete Stories of Flannery O'Connor is a compilation of all the short stories written by Flannery O'Connor during her lifetime. Although she wrote mostly fiction, this book gives readers a taste of the different genres she experimented with. The stories range from the absurd to the religious, but all offer a glimpse into the human condition.
129:
The Complete Stories of Franz Kafka
by Franz Kafka

The Complete Stories of Franz Kafka is a collection of Kafka's short stories, unfinished works, and sketches. The stories are dark and often surreal, dealing with themes of alienation, existential anxiety, and paranoia. Many of the stories are unfinished, and the collection as a whole gives a fascinating glimpse into Kafka's creative process.
130:
The Complete Tales and Poems of Edgar Allan Poe
by Edgar Allan Poe

The book "The Complete Tales and Poems of Edgar Allan Poe" is a collection of short stories and poems by Edgar Allan Poe. The stories are mostly in the horror genre, and the poems are mostly about love and loss.
131:
The Corrections
by Jonathan Franzen

"The Corrections" is a novel by Jonathan Franzen, published in 2001. The novel tells the story of the dysfunctional Lambert family, and their struggles to deal with their problems. The novel was a finalist for the National Book Award, and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.
132:
The Count of Monte Cristo
by Alexandre Dumas

The book is an adventure story about a man who is wrongfully imprisoned, escapes, and takes revenge on those who betrayed him. It is set during the Napoleonic era in France and Italy. The book is considered one of Dumas' best works.
133:
The Divine Comedy
by Dante Alighieri

The Divine Comedy by Dante Alighieri is a classic Italian epic poem. It tells the story of Dante's journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise. The poem is widely considered to be one of the greatest works of world literature.
134:
The Flowers of Evil
by Charles Baudelaire

The Flowers of Evil is a collection of poems by Charles Baudelaire. The poems deal with themes of love, death, decay, and other dark topics. The collection was controversial at the time of its publication, due to its frank treatment of these taboo subjects.
135:
The Golden Notebook
by Doris Lessing

"The Golden Notebook" by Doris Lessing is a novel about a writer who tries to make sense of her life by writing it all down in a series of notebooks. The book is split into four sections, each representing a different stage in her life. The first section is about her childhood in Southern Rhodesia, the second is about her time as a student in England, the third is about her marriage and work as a journalist in London, and the fourth is about her life as a single mother in the countryside.
136:
The Good Soldier
by Ford Madox Ford

"The Good Soldier" is a novel by Ford Madox Ford that tells the story of two couples - one British, one American - whose lives intersect during World War I. The novel is told from the perspective of the British husband, who slowly comes to realize that his wife is having an affair with the American husband. As the war progresses and the two couples' lives become more and more intertwined, the British husband's grip on reality begins to unravel.
137:
The Grapes of Wrath
by John Steinbeck

The Grapes of Wrath is a novel by John Steinbeck that was published in 1939. The novel is set during the Great Depression and tells the story of the Joad family, who are forced to leave their farm in Oklahoma and travel to California in search of work. The novel is considered a classic of American literature and won the Pulitzer Prize in 1940.
138:
The Great Gatsby
by F. Scott Fitzgerald

The Great Gatsby is a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald. The novel tells the story of Jay Gatsby and his unrequited love for the beautiful Daisy Buchanan. The novel is set in the 1920s and is a critique of the American Dream.
139:
The Handmaid's Tale
by Margaret Atwood

"The Handmaid's Tale" is a dystopian novel about a society where women are treated as property and are largely confined to the home. The story follows the handmaid Offred, who is assigned to the household of the Commander, Fred Waterford. Offred is tasked with bearing children for the Commander and his wife, but she is also a reluctant participant in the rebellion against the government's oppressive regime.
140:
The Hobbit
by J. R. R. Tolkien

The Hobbit is a book by J. R. R. Tolkien. It is a fantasy novel, and it is about a hobbit named Bilbo Baggins who goes on an adventure with a group of dwarves.
141:
The Hound of the Baskervilles
by Arthur Conan Doyle

"The Hound of the Baskervilles" is a detective novel by Arthur Conan Doyle, first published in 1902. The novel is set in Devon, England, in the late 19th century, and revolves around the mystery of the death of Sir Charles Baskerville. The novel is considered one of the best works of detective fiction ever written.
142:
The House of Mirth
by Edith Wharton

The House of Mirth is a novel by Edith Wharton that was first published in 1905. The book tells the story of Lily Bart, a young woman from a wealthy family who is trying to find a husband who can support her lavish lifestyle. Lily's search for a wealthy husband leads her into a series of relationships and social interactions that ultimately result in her downfall.
143:
The House of the Spirits
by Isabel Allende

"The House of the Spirits" is a novel by Isabel Allende that tells the story of the Trueba family, spanning three generations. The novel is magical realist, which means that it contains elements of both reality and fantasy. The story follows the family as they experience love, loss, and political upheaval in their native Chile.
144:
The Idiot
by Fyodor Dostoyevsky

The Idiot by Fyodor Dostoyevsky follows the story of Prince Lev Nikolayevich Myshkin, a kind and simple man who is considered an idiot because of his innocence. He moves to St. Petersburg and becomes friends with a woman named Nastasya Filippovna, who is beautiful but has a dark past. Myshkin falls in love with her, but she is not interested in him and instead marries a wealthy man. Myshkin's innocence is eventually his downfall, and he is forced to leave St. Petersburg.
145:
The Iliad
by Homer

The Iliad is an epic poem by Homer, one of the oldest surviving works of literature. The poem tells the story of the ten-year siege of the city of Troy by the Greek armies, and the eventual fall of the city. The Iliad is full of intense battle scenes, and is one of the most famous works of literature in the Western tradition.
146:
The Leopard
by Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa

The Leopard is a historical novel by Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa, published in 1958. The novel is set in the 1860s and tells the story of a declining Sicilian nobilityman, the Prince of Salina, and his attempts to maintain his family's position in the face of the political and social changes that are sweeping through the island.
147:
The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe
by C. S. Lewis

"The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe" is a novel written by C. S. Lewis and published in 1950. It is the first book in the series The Chronicles of Narnia. The novel is set in the fictional world of Narnia and tells the story of four children who find a magical wardrobe that transports them to Narnia. There, they must help the lion Aslan defeat the evil White Witch.
148:
The Little Prince
by Antoine de Saint-ExupÃ©ry

The Little Prince, written by Antoine de Saint-ExupÃ©ry, is a novella, or long story. The book tells the story of a young prince who lives on a small asteroid and his journey to Earth. Along the way, the prince learns about love, loss, and what it means to be human.
149:
The Lord of the Rings
by J. R. R. Tolkien

"The Lord of the Rings" is a fantasy novel written by J. R. R. Tolkien. It was first published in 1954 and is the second novel in Tolkien's "The Middle-earth" series. The novel tells the story of a group of Hobbits who must destroy the One Ring to prevent the Dark Lord Sauron from enslaving the people of Middle-earth.
150:
The Magic Mountain
by Thomas Mann

"The Magic Mountain" by Thomas Mann is a novel about a young man, Hans Castorp, who goes to visit a cousin at a tuberculosis sanatorium in the Swiss Alps and ends up staying for seven years. The novel is an exploration of sickness, death, and the human condition, as well as a social critique of early 20th-century Europe.
151:
The Man Without Qualities
by Robert Musil

The Man Without Qualities by Robert Musil is a modernist novel set in pre-World War I Vienna. The novel chronicles the life of an aimless man named Ulrich who becomes caught up in a plot to assassinate the Archduke Franz Ferdinand. The novel is a satire of the Austrian aristocracy and a critique of the meaningless of modern life.
152:
The Master and Margarita
by Mikhail Bulgakov

The Master and Margarita is a novel by Mikhail Bulgakov, written in the Soviet Union between 1928 and 1940 during the Stalinist era. The story revolves around the devil, who comes to Moscow disguised as a professor, and the master, a writer who is being persecuted by the Soviet secret police. The devil chaos and the master's love for Margarita, a young woman who is also being pursued by the secret police, ultimately lead to the master's death.
153:
The Metamorphosis
by Franz Kafka

The Metamorphosis by Franz Kafka is a novella about a man named Gregor Samsa who wakes up one day to find that he has turned into a giant insect. The story follows Gregor as he tries to adjust to his new life and how his family and society react to his transformation. The Metamorphosis is a dark comedy that explores themes of isolation, family, and society.
154:
The Moviegoer
by Walker Percy

"The Moviegoer" is a novel by Walker Percy, set in New Orleans in the early 1960s. The protagonist, Binx Bolling, is a young man who is searching for meaning in his life. He turns to movies as a way to escape from his mundane existence. The novel is a contemplation of the human condition and what it means to be alive.
155:
The Odyssey
by Homer

The Odyssey is an epic poem by Homer, recounting the journey of the Greek hero Odysseus as he tries to return home after the Trojan War. Along the way, he faces challenges posed by the sea itself, as well as by the various creatures and people he encounters. The poem is written in a poetic form known as dactylic hexameter.
156:
The Old Man and the Sea
by Ernest Hemingway

"The Old Man and the Sea" is a novel by Ernest Hemingway, published in 1952. It tells the story of an aging Cuban fisherman who struggles to catch a giant marlin in the Gulf Stream off the coast of Cuba. The novel was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1953 and was cited by the Nobel Committee as contributing to their decision to award the Nobel Prize in Literature to Hemingway in 1954.
157:
The Pickwick Papers
by Charles Dickens

The Pickwick Papers is a novel by Charles Dickens, published in serial form between 1836 and 1837. The novel follows the adventures of Mr. Pickwick and his friends as they travel around England. Along the way, they get into a number of comical situations and meet a variety of colorful characters. The novel is a comic masterpiece and is considered one of Dickens' best works.
158:
The Plague
by Albert Camus

The book "The Plague" by Albert Camus is a novel about the outbreak of a plague in the Algerian city of Oran. The book is divided into five sections, each of which chronicles a different aspect of the outbreak. The first section chronicles the arrival of the plague in Oran and the response of the city's residents. The second section chronicles the quarantine of the city and the attempts of the residents to cope with the plague. The third section chronicles the outbreak of violence in the city as the residents attempt to flee the plague. The fourth section chronicles the return of the survivors to Oran and the rebuilding of the city. The fifth and final section chronicles the aftermath of the plague and the impact it had on the lives of the survivors.
159:
The Portrait of a Lady
by Henry James

The Portrait of a Lady is a novel by Henry James, first published in 1881. It is one of James's most popular novels, and is regarded as one of his major works. The novel tells the story of Isabel Archer, an independent and spirited young American woman who moves to England to live with her cousin Ralph Touchett. There, she meets and falls in love with the charming but corrupt Gilbert Osmond, who manipulates her into marrying him. The novel is a study of Isabel's psychological development and her growth into maturity, as she comes to realize the true nature of Gilbert's character.
160:
The Possessed
by Fyodor Dostoyevsky

"The Possessed" is a novel by Fyodor Dostoyevsky, first published in 1872. The novel tells the story of a group of radical intellectuals in 19th-century Russia, and the tragic consequences of their revolutionary fervor. The Possessed is considered one of Dostoyevsky's masterpieces, and is one of the most important works of Russian literature.
161:
The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
by Muriel Spark

The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie is a novel by Muriel Spark. It is set in Edinburgh in the 1930s, and tells the story of Miss Jean Brodie, a teacher at a girls' school, and her pupils. The novel is satirical and explores the themes of education, morality, and religion.
162:
The Princess of Cleves
by Madame de La Fayette

Published in 1678, "The Princess of Cleves" is a French historical novel by Madame de La Fayette. Set in the court of Henry II of France, it tells the story of a princess who falls in love with a duke, against the wishes of her family. The novel is considered one of the first psychological novels in Western literature.
163:
The Red and the Black
by Stendhal

"The Red and the Black" is a novel by Stendhal, published in 1830. The novel is set in France during the Napoleonic era. It tells the story of a young man, Julien Sorel, who is determined to make his way in society, despite his humble origins. The novel is a satire of the society of the time, and is also a study of human ambition and morality.
164:
The Remains of the Day
by Kazuo Ishiguro

The Remains of the Day is a novel by Kazuo Ishiguro that was published in 1989. The novel is set in England between the World Wars and follows the life of Stevens, a butler who is struggling to come to terms with his past. The novel is a tragedy and explores the themes of class, love, and regret.
165:
The Scarlet Letter
by Nathaniel Hawthorne

The Scarlet Letter is a book written by Nathaniel Hawthorne and published in 1850. The book is set in Puritan Massachusetts Bay Colony during the years 1642 to 1649. The book tells the story of Hester Prynne, a woman who is publicly humiliated and forced to wear a scarlet letter A after she is found guilty of adultery. Hester's lover, the book's protagonist, the Reverend Arthur Dimmesdale, is also guilty of adultery but he does not publicly acknowledge his sin. The book explores themes of sin, guilt, and redemption.
166:
The Sea, The Sea
by Iris Murdoch

"The Sea, The Sea" is a novel by Iris Murdoch. It is a story about a man who returns to his hometown by the sea and becomes obsessed with a woman he used to know. The novel is a mix of genres, including romance, mystery, and thriller.
167:
The Sound and the Fury
by William Faulkner

The Sound and the Fury is a novel by William Faulkner. The novel tells the story of the Compson family, a family from the American South, and their decline. The novel is told from the point of view of three different characters: Benjy, Quentin, and Jason. The novel is a tragedy.
168:
The Stories of Anton Chekhov
by Anton Chekhov

The Stories of Anton Chekhov is a collection of short stories written by Anton Chekhov. The stories are mostly realistic, with some elements of the supernatural. They cover a wide range of topics, from love and marriage to death and despair.
169:
The Stories of John Cheever
by John Cheever

The Stories of John Cheever is a collection of short stories by American writer John Cheever, first published in 1978. It won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction and the National Book Critics Circle Award. The stories are set in suburban New York and deal with themes of infidelity, alcoholism, and suburban ennui.
170:
The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
by Robert Louis Stevenson

The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a gothic horror novel written by Robert Louis Stevenson and published in 1886. The novel follows the story of Dr. Henry Jekyll, a scientist who creates a potion that unleashes the dark side of his personality, Mr. Edward Hyde. As Hyde begins to take over Jekyll's life, the doctor must race to find a cure before it's too late.
171:
The Stranger
by Albert Camus

The Stranger is a novel by Albert Camus about a French Algerian man, Meursault, who is unemotional and indifferent about life, even after his mother's death. The story is set in Algeria in the 1940s and is a first-person narrative. Meursault's trial and execution form the central action of the story.
172:
The Sun Also Rises
by Ernest Hemingway

"The Sun Also Rises" is a novel by Ernest Hemingway that tells the story of a group of American and British expatriates who travel from Paris to the Festival of San FermÃ­n in Pamplona to watch the running of the bulls and the bullfights. The novel is considered to be one of Hemingway's greatest works, and is one of the most-read novels of the 20th century.
173:
The Tale of Genji
by Murasaki Shikibu

The Tale of Genji is a classic work of Japanese literature written in the early 11th century. It is considered one of the masterpieces of world literature, and has had a significant influence on subsequent works in both East and West. The genre of the book is a novel, and the plot follows the life and loves of the "shining prince" Genji, as well as the politics and culture of Heian Japan.
174:
The Tempest
by William Shakespeare

"The Tempest" is a play by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written in 1610-11 and thought by many critics to be the last play that Shakespeare wrote alone. It is set on a remote island, where the sorcerer Prospero, rightful Duke of Milan, plots to restore his daughter Miranda to her rightful place using illusion and skillful manipulation. The play contains elements of tragedy, comedy, and romance.
175:
The Tin Drum
by GÃ¼nter Grass

The Tin Drum is a novel by GÃ¼nter Grass, first published in 1959. It is the first book of Grass's Danzig Trilogy. The novel is set in Danzig, a city on the Baltic Sea, between the two world wars. It tells the story of Oskar Matzerath, a boy who decides to stop growing at the age of three.
176:
The Trial
by Franz Kafka

The Trial is a novel by Franz Kafka that was first published in 1925. The book is set in a nameless city and tells the story of a man who is arrested and put on trial for an unknown crime. The novel has been interpreted as a satire on the legal system, and as a commentary on the human condition.
177:
The Waste Land
by T. S. Eliot

"The Waste Land" is a poem by T. S. Eliot, first published in 1922. The poem is considered to be one of the most important works of modernist poetry. The poem is divided into five sections, each of which contains a number of smaller subsections. The poem is concerned with the search for meaning in a world that has been rendered meaningless by the First World War.
178:
The Waves
by Virginia Woolf

The Waves is a novel by Virginia Woolf that was first published in 1931. The book is set in England and follows the lives of several friends from childhood to adulthood. The Waves is considered to be one of Woolf's most experimental novels, and it is known for its stream-of-consciousness style of writing.
179:
The Wind in the Willows
by Kenneth Grahame

The Wind in the Willows is a children's book by Kenneth Grahame, first published in 1908. Alternately slow moving and fast paced, it focuses on four anthropomorphised animal characters in a pastoral version of Edwardian England. The novel is notable for its mixture of mysticism, adventure, morality, and camaraderie, and celebrated for its evocation of the natural world.
180:
The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
by Haruki Murakami

The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle is a novel by Haruki Murakami. The novel is a surrealist story that follows the life of Toru Okada and his search for his missing cat, Noboru Wataya. The story is set in Tokyo and has elements of mystery, thriller, and magical realism.
181:
The World According to Garp
by John Irving

The World According to Garp is a novel by John Irving. It is a satire of the traditional novel, and is set in the postwar United States. The novel follows the life of T. S. Garp, from his birth in 1945 to his death in 1981. Garp is the son of a feminist mother, Jenny Fields, and is raised in a feminist commune. He becomes a writer, and his life is marked by tragedy and comedy.
182:
Their Eyes Were Watching God
by Zora Neale Hurston

"Their Eyes Were Watching God" is a novel by Zora Neale Hurston that was published in 1937. It is considered one of the most important works of the Harlem Renaissance. The novel tells the story of Janie Crawford, a black woman who is searching for her identity and true love.
183:
Things Fall Apart
by Chinua Achebe

"Things Fall Apart" is a novel written by Chinua Achebe that tells the story of Okonkwo, a man from the Igbo tribe in Nigeria. The novel chronicles Okonkwo's rise to power and eventual fall, and explores themes of tradition, culture, and colonialism.
184:
To Kill a Mockingbird
by Harper Lee

To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee, set in the small town of Maycomb, Alabama, during the 1930s. The novel centers on the Finch family and their interactions with their African American neighbors. The novel explores the themes of prejudice, innocence, and morality.
185:
To the Lighthouse
by Virginia Woolf

"To the Lighthouse" is a novel by Virginia Woolf, published in 1927. The novel follows the lives of the Ramsay family and their guests at their home on the Isle of Skye. The novel is set in three parts, each focusing on a different time period. The first part is set in the summer of 1910, the second in the summer of 1918, and the third in the summer of 1921. The novel is Woolf's most experimental work, and it is considered a landmark of modernist literature.
186:
Tom Jones
by Henry Fielding

Tom Jones is a novel by Henry Fielding. The novel is both a comic and moral tale. The plot follows the story of Tom Jones, a foundling, as he grows up and tries to figure out his place in the world. Along the way, he has many adventures and gets into a lot of trouble. The novel is full of humor and satire.
187:
Treasure Island
by Robert Louis Stevenson

"Treasure Island" is a novel by Robert Louis Stevenson, first published in 1883. It is an adventure story, set in the 18th century, that tells the story of Jim Hawkins, a young boy who finds a map of a pirate treasure island and sets off on a journey to find it. Along the way, he meets a cast of characters, both good and bad, who help or hinder his quest.
188:
Tristram Shandy
by Laurence Sterne

"Tristram Shandy" is a novel by Laurence Sterne, first published in 1759. The book is a satire of the conventions of the novel, and is also a self-conscious examination of the process of writing a novel. The book is divided into nine volumes, each of which is further divided into chapters. The first volume tells the story of Tristram's birth, and the subsequent volumes chronicle his life, his loves, and his many digressions.
189:
Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea
by Jules Verne

"Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea" is a novel written by Jules Verne in the late 1800s. The book tells the story of an underwater expedition led by the eccentric Captain Nemo. The crew of the submarine, the Nautilus, explore the depths of the ocean, encountering strange and dangerous creatures along the way. The novel is considered to be one of the earliest examples of science fiction.
190:
Ulysses
by James Joyce

"Ulysses" by James Joyce is a novel set in Dublin, Ireland during the early twentieth century. It follows the lives of a number of characters over the course of a single day, June 16, 1904. The novel is Joyce's retelling of Homer's Odyssey, with the main character, Leopold Bloom, taking on the role of Ulysses. The novel is considered to be one of the most important works of modernist literature.
191:
Under the Volcano
by Malcolm Lowry

Under the Volcano is a novel by Malcolm Lowry published in 1947. The novel tells the story of Geoffrey Firmin, an alcoholic British consul in the small town of Quauhnahuac, Mexico, on the eve of the Mexican Revolution. The novel is widely considered one of the greatest works of 20th-century literature.
192:
Vanity Fair
by William Makepeace Thackeray

"Vanity Fair" is a novel by William Makepeace Thackeray, first published in 1847-48. The book is a satire of society during the Napoleonic Wars. The story follows the lives of Becky Sharp and Amelia Sedley, two young women who enter society with very different expectations.
193:
Waiting for Godot
by Samuel Beckett

"Waiting for Godot" is a play by Samuel Beckett, in which two tramps wait endlessly and in vain for the arrival of someone named Godot. It is a tragicomedy, mixing elements of both tragedy and comedy. The plot is largely circular and repetitive, with the two main characters passing the time by talking, arguing, and playing games.
194:
War and Peace
by Leo Tolstoy

"War and Peace" is a novel by Leo Tolstoy, first published in 1869. The work is regarded as one of the finest novels ever written, and Tolstoy himself called it his first true novel. It tells the story of the French invasion of Russia and the resulting war, interspersed with scenes from the lives of the Russian aristocratic families.
195:
White Teeth
by Zadie Smith

"White Teeth" is a novel by Zadie Smith, first published in 2000. The novel is set in London and follows the lives of two families - one white British and the other Bangladeshi immigrant - over several decades, from the 1940s to the 1990s. The novel is a comic drama that explores themes of race, identity and immigration.
196:
Wide Sargasso Sea
by Jean Rhys

The book "Wide Sargasso Sea" by Jean Rhys is a novel set in the Caribbean during the early 1800s. It tells the story of Antoinette Cosway, a white Creole woman who is married off to an Englishman, Mr. Rochester. The marriage quickly deteriorates, and Antoinette is locked away in a madhouse by her husband. The novel is a study of race, sexism, and colonialism, and its effects on Antoinette's mental health.
197:
Women in Love
by D. H. Lawrence

"Women in Love" is a novel by D. H. Lawrence, first published in 1920. It is a story about the love between two women, Gudrun Brangwen and Ursula Brangwen. The novel is set in England and Wales, and explores the relationships between the two women, as well as the social and political climate of the time.
198:
Wuthering Heights
by Emily BrontÃ©

"Wuthering Heights" is a novel by Emily BrontÃ©. The novel is set in the Yorkshire moors and follows the story of Heathcliff, a foundling who is taken in by the Earnshaw family. Heathcliff falls in love with Catherine Earnshaw, but she is forced to marry Edgar Linton instead. Heathcliff becomes obsessed with revenge and Catherine's ghost haunt the moors.
